testimony: Good morning to you all.  This is the first sitting of the Amnesty Committee, today being the 20th of September 1999.  The Hearing taking place at the Durban Christian Centre.  The first application which is set down on the roll is the one of Moses Mtu Dlamini, application no AM1574/96.  Before I proceed to request the legal representative appearing for Mr Dlamini to put his name on the roll, it is my pleasure to introduce the Members who will be sitting, listening to the evidence for the duration of all the applications set down for this week in Durban.  On my right-hand side I have Adv Chris de Jager, Senior Counsel, on my left-hand side Mr Wynand Malan.  I am Judge Sisi Khampepe.  The legal representative for Mr Dlamini, kindly place your name on the roll.
Thank you, Madam Chair.  Madam Chair, my name is Mr Panday, initial S and I confirm my appearance for the applicant.
Chairperson I am Lulama Mtanga the Evidence Leader.  Thank you.
Thank you.  Mr Panday, are we in a position to commence with hearing the evidence of Mr Dlamini?
Yes.  Will Mr Dlamini be giving evidence in Zulu?
Has he been shown how to use our headphones?
I am not aware of that Madam.
Mr Dlamini is it correct that you are an applicant for amnesty herein?
Mr Dlamini, is it further correct that you were sentenced for the crime of murder and possession of a firearm during 1994 with four others?
Mr Dlamini during the commission of that offence ...(intervention).

Mr Panday, is it correct that he received a sentence of 8 years imprisonment for the murder and 1 year imprisonment for the possession of a firearm and 3 months for possession of ammunition, but the last two sentences were running concurrently so he was sentenced to an effective term of imprisonment of 9 years?
Mr Chairman, I was going to get to that.  I was going to lead his evidence first as to how he found himself to the point of conviction.
Thank you.  Mr Dlamini, during 1992 when a murder took place in which you were involved, where were you resident at that time?
It was next to an airport.  There was a building there, next to a place like an airport.
And in the area that you lived, how many others lived with you?
Mr Dlamini, at that time were you a member of any political party?
Yes, I was an ANC member.
For how long were you an ANC member?
Besides being an ANC member, did you have any active role with the ANC?
Just a second, did I hear you say that you have been a member of the ANC from 1973?
That is what I heard as well, Chairperson.
I take the point, Chairperson, I was going to get to it.
Then get to it please, Mr Panday.
Mr Dlamini, if you were born in 1975, how is it that you're now and ANC member since 1973?
The police made some confusion during the writing down of the statement.  I told them that I was born in 1969.
Mr Dlamini, if you were born in 1969, in 1973 you would have only been 4 years old.  Are you sure that you were still a member of the ANC since 1973?
Yes, I am sure, I am certain about that.
Mr Panday, you are not incorrect in your calculation yourself?
Madam Chair, if he was born in 1969, as he says he was and if he had to be a member since 1973, that would make him approximately 4 years, since 1973 - sorry, I understand, I take the point.
Let's quickly get over this.  Won't you just ask the question pointedly?
Mr Dlamini, in 1973 you would have been 4 years old, is that correct, if you were born in 1969?
Now I ask you again, if you were 4 years old, how did you even know of the ANC back then?
My parents used to tell me about it.

The question is very easy.  We would request you to listen carefully to the question and answer the question only if you understand the question.  I am going to rather warn you, the time in the hands of the Committee is very short.  We want to request you to answer the question according to what you know and as a person who is under oath.  You have testified that you have joined and became a member of a political organisation, ANC that is, in 1973.  Was that the truth?
My parents were ANC members from 1973.
In this Hearing we do not want to know anything that does not concern you.  We don't want to hear any evidence that does not reside within you.  Do you understand?

The question when you joined the ANC, you must tell us what you yourself did to join the ANC.  We don't want to hear evidence about your family's association with the ANC.  We want your personal involvement with the ANC.  Did you at any stage have anything to do with the ANC as a political organisation?
From 1990, here at Tongaat, that is when I met with the ANC people and even the place that we were residing at.
When you allude to meeting with the ANC people, what do you mean?  You stayed in the company of people?
Yes, I was staying with them.  We were made to join and we bought some membership cards for ANC, that is when we became full members of ANC.
You joined the ANC by paying a membership fee to a particular person, is that what you are saying?
I had a choice to do that.  I did not do that because I was forced.
My question does not seek to elicit whether you were forced or not.  All that I seek to find out is that you became a member of the ANC by paying a membership fee.
How did you become a member of the ANC in 1990?
That is the organisation that I grew up in front of.
Mr Dlamini, would you say that during your growing up, the organisation that you believed in was the ANC?
Won't you try and put the question pointedly, Mr Panday?  I thought the ground had already been laid that he wasn't really a member, he was really a supporter.
Yes, Madam Chairperson.  Mr Dlamini, just to clarify the point raised by the Madam Chair, is it correct that you were a supporter of the ANC and not a member of any structure in the ANC?
I cannot say for sure that I was a supporter because all I know is that I was a member, I was ANC, that is all I know.
You did not have a card, isn't that so?  A joining card, the one that you had to pay a membership fee for?
I did not have a card, yes, that is true.
Mr Dlamini, when you were residing in Tongaat, was the entire area that you resided in supporters of the ANC?
Yes, that is correct.  They were only ANC members.
Now during 1992, in the area that you resided in, who was in charge of the people that lived in the airport area?
Is it correct that Lucky Ntshetha was one of the accused in your criminal matter?
Now, you mentioned that Lucky Ntshetha was in charge.  What position did he hold in the ANC?
He was a person whom we would forward our grievances or complaints to.
Sorry you mentioned you would forward your grievances and complaints to?
Sorry, if I understand you correctly, are you saying that you put your complaints to Lucky?
The question, Mr Dlamini, that Mr Panday put to you was, did Lucky hold a position in the ANC structures?  Do you know?
He did not hold any position but he was a person who was appointed by us to be in charge in the area.
So is it correct that when there was a problem you saw him as leader?
Won't you qualify what kind of a problem you are referring to so that he can be more precise in his response?
Mr Dlamini, if you all had a problem in the area, if someone was fighting with the people in the area, is it correct that you all would then complain to Lucky?
And is it also correct that Lucky would then decide what has to be done with any problems in the area?
Yes, he would take a decision.
Did any of Lucky's - did you personally have to follow any of Lucky's decisions or orders that were taken?
Can you tell us, Mr Dlamini, why you had to follow orders and decisions of Lucky?
The reason for that, it's solely because everything that we did, we did it under his authority.  Most of the mistakes, he would - the one who would solve the problems of the community.
If you talk about the community, are you talking about the 16 people who lived together, or what community are you talking about?
Yes, those people who were residing with us in the area.
The question is, are you referring to the 16 people?
Yes, I'm referring to those 16 people.
Mr Dlamini, we're going to go back to now 1992 when you, together with four others, were charged for the murder of a person.

May I interpose before you proceed to 1992?  We feel it is important for us to be fully informed about how the applicant saw Mr Ntshetha as a leader and for him to tell us when he elected him, or appointed him as his leader.
When did you appoint Mr Ntshetha as your leader?

...(indistinct) Ntshetha was appointed on the day when the violence erupted when the IFP people came who wanted to force us to join IFP and the youth from the area ran away to a place that was an airport where we were staying.
Yes, when I say when, I want you to give me an indication with regard to a year and if possible, the month.  When was it, was it in 1980, 1990, 19 -  what year are we talking about?
That took place in 1990 on the 2nd of February.
Yes, you may proceed Mr Panday.
Sorry, just before you proceed, Mr Panday I am - from the record it seems that the applicant is illiterate Mr Panday, is that so?

Then I just want to put it to you, Mr Dlamini that we have a statement taken from Mr Ntshetha, from Lucky, in which he says that he moved to the airport area and it seems, if we look at the chronology of his statement, shortly before the incident and that you and others had already been living at that airport shacks, he joined you and he met you there.  Is that correct, that you were living already in that area when Lucky arrived there?
How do you know it was 1990?
That is the time when we arrived at the place and when he came he found us there, we had been staying there for a short while, three weeks if I'm not mistaken, we had been staying there.
Now who was the leader before he arrived?
We were working with a person called Basil.
Can we just get that name again?
We were working with a person called Basil.
Thank you Mr Panday, you may proceed.
Mr Dlamini just to confirm, clarify, you say you were working for a person called Basil, was Basil in charge of the 16 people, or did you just work for Basil?

Basil was not a leader, he was just a brave person, we were working with him because he was brave and we were discussing as what to do when a problem comes, therefore we would try and solve problems, me and him, the two of us.
This Basil, was he a co-accused with you in this trial?
Yes, he is one of the accused.
Was Basil also an ANC supporter?
Yes, Mr Panday, all 16 of them were ANC supporters.  You may now move into the main incident.  I actually interrupted you when you were now taking the applicant into the incident itself.

Mr Dlamini, we're now going to go back to 1992, where you, together with 4 others, were involved in the murder of a person.  Now Mr Dlamini, I want for you to explain to the Commission how you became involved and partook in the murder of that person.

Mr Ntshetha was in his room in the morning.  He came to my room and he said to me:  "Moses, there's a person who is just next to my door with a firearm and I want you to go there with me."  I woke up and I called upon the others and we left to the place, all of us.  We saw this person and I pointed him with a gun and I told him to put whatever, what was in his hand down.  He did so and we took him with, we investigated him and we wanted to know where he came from and he told us.
Mr Dlamini, let's go back step by step now.  First we had Lucky come to you and say to you that there is a person by his room with a gun, is that correct?
Thereafter, you rounded up the others and you all went to approach this person, who came to attack Mr Lucky, is that correct?
Mr Panday, did he give evidence that this person was to attack him?  Was his evidence not simply that there was a person?
I apologise, Mr Chairman.  Mr Dlamini, did Lucky tell you what this person came to his room for?
Yes, he told us everything before going to that place.
What is it that Lucky did tell you?
He said he had seen a person in front of his door with a firearm and then he tried to use a back door.
Mr Dlamini, you thereafter mentioned that you had approached this person and pointed a firearm at him.  Who pointed the firearm?
Myself, I pointed him with a firearm.
And when you pointed the firearm at him, what did he do?
I did that and I made him to put his firearm down.  Ntshetha is the one who picked up his firearm and we drove him to the place where I was staying.  We drove him to my room.
Sorry, before you proceed with this, when you - where did you find this person?
We found him sitting under a tree, that is where we found him.  He was no longer at the door or in front of the door.
It was next to Sinangwenye's house.
Is that next to Basil's parents' home?  Which Ngwenye are you talking about?
The tree was next to Sinangwenye's house.
Who is this Ngwenye?  Is he related to Basil?
He is also here right now.
I want to know whether he is the father of Basil.  Is he a family of Basil's?
No.  Basil was just alone, he had no member of the family there, only the youth.
Who is Lucky?  Is Lucky also known as Sinangwenye?
Yes, that was another name that we were using for him, he was Sinangwenye.
So then maybe I've misunderstood you.  Are you saying he was sitting under a tree at Lucky's house?
Yes, he was sitting under a tree, next to his house.
Mr Dlamini, we stopped at where you mentioned that "Lucky picked up a firearm and we drove him to my place."  Now were you living somewhere else at the time?
That is one area with different rooms.
What do you mean "we drove him"?  By car or how did you drive him?
So you forced him to accompany you to your place?  To your room?
Yes, we were forcing him because we were in trouble at the time.  We had to investigate him and to know his reason to be there.  We wanted to know all about that.
Mr Dlamini, when you say, "we forced him to come with us", what sort of force did you all use to take the victim with you?
I had pointed a firearm at him and the other people who were with me were also armed and we were taking him towards my house.
Mr Dlamini, when you and other people got to your house, what happened thereafter to the victim?
When we arrived there we sat down.  We started asking questions one by one.  We wanted to know where he was going to and we wanted to know where he was also coming from.  He told us everything.
Mr Dlamini what sort of questions did you ask him one by one?  What questions did you ask him?

We were questioning him about the attacks in our area and we wanted to know to which organisation did he belong to, because he knew very well that as the ANC was on the other side of the road, he was not allowed to come to the other area because killings were taking place.
Mr Dlamini you mentioned that you asked him which organisation he belonged to.  Did he tell you which organisation he belonged to?
Yes, he told us that he was an IFP member who was coming from the other side of the road.
Did he tell you people what did he come into your area for?
No, he did not tell us the whole truth, he kept on evading some questions.
How were you able to deduce that he had not disclosed the truth?
The way he was - the manner in which he was talking, when you ask him about the leader, he was not prepared to reveal the truth.  He would mention someone else who was not known to us.
Mr Dlamini you mentioned that he evaded some of your questions, what questions did he evade?  Can you think of any of those questions?
He has just responded to that, hasn't he Mr Panday?  He evaded questions pertinently relating to the names of people in the leadership structures of the ANC from whence he came.
Mr Dlamini after questioning the victim, what happened to him thereafter?

That is when we decided to take him with to a place with some lawn and we took a decision that he should be punished.  We let him go - decided to let him go and we told him not to come back there because that was not his place.
Mr Dlamini let's start all over again.  You said "We took him to a place..." ...(intervention).
Don't start, Mr Panday, you may ask questions of clarity.
As Madam Chair pleases.  Mr Dlamini, you mentioned that, "We took him to a place with some lawn", do you recall the place?
I think it's a place with some grass.
Do you recall the area that you and the others took the victim to?
Yes, I still remember that place very well.
It was the same place like the one that we were residing at, it was just nearby.
So there is no name of the area?
You thereafter mentioned that: "we took a decision to punish him".  What sort of punishment did you all administer to the victim?
It was discipline, we were hitting him with a cane.  We were using a cane that is used for fishing.
So you were using a fishing rod to assault the victim, is that correct?
Did you in any way - did you personally assault the victim with the fishing rod?
Yes, I'm the one who started the assaulting.
Can you remember how many times you assaulted the victim?
Who decided that the victim needed to be punished?
He said they took a decision that he must be punished.  Now, do you want to know who is the "they" he has referred to?
Madam Chair, the applicant earlier on indicated that they always followed orders and took instructions.

No, I mean his evidence right now, now Mr Panday, that's why I was saying we don't want to go back because he has already given evidence which, in my opinion has been quite succinct and doesn't need clarification.  They took a decision, unless you want to elicit who comprises the "they" he has referred to, you may not repeat your question.
As Madam Chair pleases.  Mr Dlamini, when you mentioned "we took a decision to assault him", how many of you took that decision?
That is a decision that was taken by all of us that he should be punished.
How many of you were there, Mr Dlamini?
The people who did that, the people who assaulted him were two and after that we let him go.
My question is, how many of you were there when you took a decision that this person must be punished?
So all the people residing at the airport rural settlement were there when this decision was taken?
Yes, all of them were there.
And were all of these people present at the time when you confronted this person as he was sitting under the tree next to Sinangwenye's place?
Yes, you may proceed Mr Panday.
Mr Dlamini after assaulting the victim, what did you all do with the victim thereafter?

We released him.  We told him to go.  After that, after walking just a short distance, Sinangwenye asked a question, a very difficult question, that it even became difficult for us to respond and it was decided to go and call the person back.
What question did he pose to you?

He said, he asked us if we thought about this very well, when we released this person, because he said he was afraid that this person would go and get other IFP members to come back and attack us as usual.
After Lucky asked the question, what did you all do thereafter in response to his question?
Some of us went to fetch him and they brought him back and it was further discussed as to what was going to happen.  Sinangwenye said the best option is to kill this person.
So is it correct that Lucky took the decision to have this person killed?

May I just, for my own clarity, summarise this very briefly, Mr Dlamini?  Am I correct in understanding that the first decision was simply to punish him, that two of you hit him with that cane, the fishing rod cane, each gave him 16 lashes and you ordered him then to leave.  He was released.  As he was walking away, Lucky said something to the effect that "What happens if he comes with the Inkatha people for some revenge attack?" and suggested that it would be better that he be killed.  That you then went, apprehended the person and brought him back.  Is this summary correct?
So when he was first questioned, there was no decision to kill him then but simply to punish him.
Yes, that was the agreement, that he should be punished and be released after the punishment.
Mr Dlamini, after the decision was taken to kill the victim, did you all take the victim anywhere else to have him killed or was he killed where you all were originally?
Yes, we took him to another place where he was going to be killed.
Do you know what is the name of the place you all took him to?
It was not a distance, it was just a place nearby where there were gum trees, that is where we killed him.
Mr Dlamini, is it correct that that area is referred to as Ndwedwe area?
I can say Ndwedwe is a farm area where Lucky Ntshetha used to stay.  Ndwedwe is quite at a distance from that particular place.

So the victim was going to be killed  not too
from where 16 people resided, is that correct?
Hasn't he given evidence to that?  That he was taken to a nearby gum tree plantation?
As Madam Chair pleases.  Mr Dlamini, when the victim was taken to this gum tree plantation, who was it that either shot or stabbed the victim?  Was it all of you, or was it one specific person?
Won't you stop asking leading questions?  Just ask him how the deceased was killed.  There is no evidence before us from the applicant that the deceased was killed through any kind of stabbing.
Yes, Madam Chair.  Mr Dlamini, how was the victim killed?

I pointed a firearm at him as I was trying to shoot him, but the firearm just locked and in that situation you were forced to get another weapon.  That is when Lucky Ntshetha used a spear.  That's how he killed him.
So it is correct for us to assume that you attempted to kill the victim first by shooting him but the firearm unfortunately did not fire.
Mr Dlamini, where was the deceased at the time?  Was he being held by anybody?  Was he free-standing?  Was he running away?  Where was the deceased when he was killed?
He was tied to a tree.
Now, do I understand you correctly that when you took him to the plantation, this was after he had been released and taken in again, you have now decided to kill him?
Then you took him to the gum trees and you tied him to a tree?
Did you tie him to the tree with his back against the tree, or with his stomach towards the tree?
He was tied to a tree with his back on the stem of the tree and the chest was slightly bent.
We did not want him to try to escape.
But you were going to shoot him, why didn't you simply shoot him?  Why did you tie him up first?
It is because it was realised that it was very difficult to shoot him, therefore we had to use a spear.

No, Mr Dlamini.  Let's - please keep to the truth and if you don't tell us the truth and if eventually we don't believe you, we can't grant you amnesty, so we want the whole truth.  When you tried to shoot him, was he already tied to the tree?
Yes, he was already tied to the tree.
Right.  Now my question is, why did you have to tie him to a tree in order to shoot him?

That was a place that was more like a forest, therefore we couldn't trust him because the forest was quite big and we decided to tie him to a tree so that he couldn't escape, so that we can kill him at the time.
Now, when you punished him, was he tied or was he being held?
He was not tied.  We made him to lie down.
Now what did you tie him with when you eventually tied him to the tree after recapturing him?
Where did you get the wires?
They were available in the area.
No, where did you get the wires, Mr Dlamini?
In the place where was killed, there was an old house.  We got those wires from that old house.
So who went to fetch the wires?
We sent a child to fetch them.
Now how did you know that the child would get the wires in the old house?
We were sure, we were certain that he was going to get the wires there because we had seen them before in this old house.
And who was this child that you had sent?
You mentioned that after you tried shooting the victim, Lucky brought a spear to stab the victim, is that correct?
Where did Lucky get the spear from?
That was his weapon that he was using, the one that he used to protect himself with.
Mr Dlamini, after Lucky had stabbed the victim, what was done thereafter to the victim?
How many times did Lucky stab the victim?
I remember that he stabbed him about three times.
On which part of his body?
Did anyone else assault or stab the victim?
Now Mr Dlamini, after Lucky had stabbed the victim three times, what did all of you do with the victim thereafter?
He died and he fell down and we realised that he was no longer breathing and some of us left the scene.
Can you recall which of you had left the scene?
Just before you proceed with that, you say he died and fell down, was he not tied to the tree with wire?
We had untied him at the time.
Now at what stage did you untie him?  Did you untie him before he was stabbed or immediately after he was stabbed?
After he was stabbed, after we had realised that he was dead and we untied him.
Yes.  After Lucky had stabbed him three times and after you thought he was now dead, it's then that you untied him and he fell down?
Mr Dlamini, getting back to our question, you mentioned that  "some of us left after stabbing the victim".  Can you recall who were the parties that left the area?
We went up because on our way back the children were in front.

Please listen.  Your counsel asked you:  "Who were the persons leaving the scene after he fell to the ground?"  Did you stay there?  Did Lucky stay there?  Tell us the names of the people who left the scene.
Mr Dlamini, give us the names of the children.
Fano and Bekho as well as Basil Ngwenye, Michael Khumalo and Sepo whose surname I have forgotten.  This would also include myself as well as Lucky Ntshetha.
Sorry Mr Dlamini, just to clarify, you mentioned Fano left, Bekho left, Basil left, Michael Khumalo left and Sepo left.  What happened to you and Lucky?
They also left.  The Sepo you are referring to, would that be Sepo Nduli?
Nobody remained behind because we had all left the scene.

Now why didn't you tell your counsel that nobody was left at the scene?  The way the question was posed to you and the way you purported to respond to it, it was as though you were still going to give us a list of those who remained behind.  Suddenly you are now saying nobody was left behind.
Nobody remained behind because we took an african path so we could not be on  a parallel to each other, we had to follow one another instead on that path back home.
Mr Dlamini, after you all had left the scene of the murder, you say you had taken a path back home, is that correct?
When you and the others reached home, what took place thereafter?
We prepared our medicine to cleanse ourselves of the bad luck.
What bad luck do you refer to Mr Dlamini?
That is the tradition according to amaZulu that after killing, one should cleanse oneself using ntelezi to cleanse oneself of the bad luck.
Did you take his heart and did you eat his heart?
I suppose you are still leading to that Mr Panday?  We'll allow you.
Mr Dlamini, after cleansing yourselves from this murder, do you know what happened to the deceased that was left behind?

No, what was used for the cleansing ceremony? I thought you were going to ask that question.  Well, if you are not, permit me to do so.  What did you use for the cleansing ceremony?  What ingredients did you use for the muti that was to be used for your cleansing?
We used some medicine including ntelezi.

Is that all you used for your cleansing?
You only used ntelezi, is that all?
Will you please repeat the question?
Are you saying the only medicine that you used in cleansing yourselves was ntelezi only?
Do you know what ingredients were used for brewing this ntelezi?
Yes, I can explain.  I am the one who brewed this ntelezi.
I plucked it, I plucked it from the veld.
You may proceed Mr Panday, I seem to have covered my point.
Mr Dlamini, after using this medicine to clean yourself, do you know what happened to the victim's body?
I had already removed myself from the scene and I did not go back there.
Do you know if anybody else had gone back to the scene?

Mr Dlamini, do you recall in the trial that you appeared in, I think it was evidence was led to the effect that the heart was removed and the eyes of the victim were removed, do you know anything of that?
What I can say is that the eyes were removed during my presence, but I cannot testify as to what happened to the heart.

What do you mean when you say that the eyes were removed during your presence?  You have given us evidence and your evidence has never alluded to eyes being removed in  your presence.  At what stage were these eyes removed in your presence?  I want you to give us a logical version of events, we don't have time to be going to and fro, that's why you have counsel who is there to ensure that we have proper evidence, meaning that it must be succinct and it must be properly led in sequence.  Now at what stage were these eyes removed in your presence?
The eyes were removed after we had untied him, that is after he had fallen down.  The eyes were removed from him as he was lying down there, after which we left.
Was it the first thing that he did on the body of the accused after he had fallen down?
Yes, that's the only thing he did.
What did he use to remove the deceased's eyes?  What instrument?
And where were the other people at the time when this removal of the eyes was being conducted by Lucky?
Others were there, all of us were actually there.

Mr Dlamini, just for your information, we have in our bundle of documents an affidavit by Lucky and on page 11 of the bundle he said that he took out only one of the eyes and someone else took out the other eye.  Do you want to comment on that?
I cannot dispute that but I am saying what I saw happen before my eyes.
So it is your version that what you saw happening was Lucky removing both eyes from the deceased, using a small knife?
And you saw no one participating but him in that gruesome act?
I cannot recall seeing any other person.
Yes.  Did you do anything else other than that?  What else was done to the deceased's body whilst you all were there?
Nothing else happened after that because we all left.
What did Lucky do with the eyes removed from the deceased's body?
He left them on the scene next to the corpse.
Did you personally ask Lucky why he had done that gruesome act?  Did you ask him why he was removing the eyes from the deceased?
Yes, I did and he explained to me.
What explanation did he proffer to you?

He said that he is doing this so that in the event of the police coming to take photographs, this should be such that the pictures or shadows, yes pictures of people, should not remain on the person's lenses.
Did you believe that explanation that was given to you by Lucky?
I was not hearing that for the first time from him.  I was used to hearing such things from other people as well.
So you are saying that was all that was done on the body of the deceased, whilst you were there?

May I just ask on this score, if you were used to this, having heard from other people as well that the eyes be taken out so as not to show the images or imprints on the lenses, why did you ask Lucky then why he was doing it?
I asked him because it was something that I was quite familiar with.  I kept hearing such a thing from other people to the effect that an image of a person can be imprinted on a person's eyes.
Are you saying that you asked him to remove the eyes or did you ask him why he had removed the eyes?
I did not ask him to remove the eyes, instead I asked him about this thing that I had heard already.
Was that before or after he had removed the eyes?  When did you ask him about this imprint on the lenses?
It was after everything had been done.
Mr Dlamini, are you now certain that after the victim was killed and the eyes were removed, nothing else was done to the victim?
Is it also correct thereafter you all went back home to cleanse yourselves of this act?
